Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is developing an innovative introductory biology course to better prepare K-8 science teachers for the increasing demands of science education. The Next Generation K-12 Science Standards, which are the national "common core" for K-12 science education, include an increased emphasis on the use of scientific practices in K-12 science education. The vision of the new standards is to more fully integrate the teaching of science concepts with inquiry-based investigations performed by the students. Because many teachers have come through a traditional method of science instruction in our colleges and universities they have no personal frame of reference upon which they can model the design of inquiry-based instruction. By designing a college biology course for preservice elementary (K-8) teachers that integrates science content, scientific processes, and scientific pedagogy, the project is increasing the ability of teachers to design and implement inquiry-based lessons and better prepare them to be effective "Next Generation" science teachers.

The impact of this project involves improving teacher quality with the expectation of having a cascading effect on the quality of science education regionally and nationally. This project is helping develop and disseminate a new way of educating science teachers that integrates the science content, practices, and pedagogy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Scientific literacy is a crucial component for decision-making and global citizenship in today’s society. In order to have a scientifically literate population, we need effective science teachers. This NSF-funded project, Next Generation Science Teacher Preparation (DUE 1245500) had the goal of improving elementary science teacher preparation by designing an introductory biology course for preservice teachers that aligns with the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) and integrates biological content with an introduction to effective methods for teaching science. This intersection of content knowledge and methods for teaching that content is called pedagogical content knowledge (PCK). It was our hypothesis that introducing future teachers to the methods of teaching science while they themselves are still learning that science at the beginning of their academic careers would be more effective at developing PCK than the traditional model of learning content and methods separately and then trying to bring them together in science teaching methods courses near the end of their program. 

 

The course we designed used evidence-based teaching practices (e.g. increased formative assessment, increased proportion of time spent on cooperative group activities) in the lecture portion of the course and inquiry-based laboratory activities to present the disciplinary core ideas, scientific practices, and cross-cutting concepts of the NGSS. This project resulted in the development of 14 inquiry-based laboratory modules and more than 30 in-class cooperative group activities. Three graduate students participated in various aspects of this research and received training in biology education research. Five undergraduate students, all of whom were preservice teachers, participated as research assistants and received training in the assessment and analysis of student learning. 

 

There is some evidence to suggest that this approach has the potential to improve elementary science teacher preparation. Students in the revised course showed small, but significant, improvements in performance on written assessments (e.g. essay questions on exams) compared to students in the pre-revision class but did not improve on multiple-choice assessments. Students who completed the revised course also showed a greater understanding of the concept of inquiry-based instruction, but this knowledge did not translate into their lesson design, where no increases in inquiry level have yet been found. It may be necessary to scaffold this approach throughout multiple science courses in order to see the desired effects in lesson design and implementation. While there is still some data to be analyzed, it seems that the single exposure to this approach is not likely to be effective in influencing the quality of elementary science teaching. We hope to continue this work by identifying collaborators in other science departments at our university to design and evaluate this approach.
